title: Beaudesert Council names street Jason Day Drive after Australian golfer
title_page: Beaudesert Council names street Jason Day Drive after Australian golfer | Daily Mail Online
text:
Well-known for his shots on the golf course, Jason Day now has his name linked with a drive of a different kind in his Queensland hometown.
The rural town of Beaudesert, roughly an hour south of Brisbane, where Day grew up, has named a street in his honour.
Aptly, it has been dubbed Jason Day Drive.
Scroll down for video
World No.2 golfer Jason Day has had a street named after him in his hometown in Queensland
Jason Day Drive sits in Beaudesert, a small town roughly an hour south of Brisbane
Mayor John Brent said the unanimous Scenic Rim Council decision was a fitting tribute to the world No.2-ranked player and the area's favourite son.
'Many locals, golf enthusiasts and non-golfers alike, have followed his career for many years from a six-year-old junior at the Beaudesert Golf Club,' Cr Brent said.
'The story of how his late father encouraged his interest in the sport after salvaging an old club from the tip is the stuff of local legend.'
A spokeswoman for Scenic Rim Council told Daily Mail Australia Jason Day Drive would sit in a new residential estate in Beaudesert but had not been constructed yet.
'Jason Day Drive is yet to be constructed however will be in the coming months. At that time, a sign unveiling will take place.'

Scenic Rim Mayor John Brent with Oakland Estate developer James Robinson where the street will sit
Last month Jason Day made headlines for a different reason entirely when his wife Ellie was bowled over by basketball star LeBron James while they sat courtside for a NBA game.
Ellie Day was sitting courtside at Quicken Loans Arena for the Cleveland Cavaliers' home match against Oklahoma City Thunder when James fell onto her.
James, who stands at an impressive 6ft 8in, was chasing a loose ball when he fell out of bounds, knocked Mrs Day's chair over and crushed the mother-of-two.
In August Day, 28, became the fifth Australian to win the PGA Championship, and the first player to finish 20-under-par at a major.
